block.p: Attractions
Museums

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, 1120 Fifth Avenue, at 103rd Street. Tomorrow at 3 p.m., a sword dance performance in celebration of the 21st New York Sword Dance Festival. Sunday at 2 p.m., a screening of ''The Cameraman'' (1928), the silent film directed by Edward Sedgwick and starring Buster Keaton, with live piano accompaniment and a discussion with the film historian Bruce Lawton. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; open Monday. Suggested admission through Sunday: $7; 62+ and students, $5; families, $15. Beginning Monday, $9; 62+ and students, $5; under 12, free; families, $20; and Sundays, 10 a.m. to noon, free for everyone. (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. ''She Made It: Women Creating Television and Radio,'' with screenings and radio programming from specific shows. Through March 23, ''She Made It On Her Own,'' featuring television shows produced by their female stars: Marlo Thomas in ''That Girl'' and Mary Tyler Moore in ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show.'' Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $8; children under 14, $5. (212) 621-6800.
Gardens

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Sunday at 3 p.m., ''A Day at the Circus,'' with music by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and circus acts by the New York Lyric Circus; free with grounds admission. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Garden grounds admission: $6; 62+, $3; students, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Combination ticket, including all admissions and a tram tour: $13; 62+ and students, $11; children 2 to 12, $5; under 2, free. Tram tours daily, every 40 minutes. Conservatory admission: $5; students and 62+, $4; 2 to 12, $3; under 2, free. Grounds admission free on Wednesdays, and 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays; parking: $7. (718) 817-8700; nybg.org.

WAVE HILL, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Tropical Rhythms,'' a family art project to make a percussion instrument, drawing inspiration from a performance by the dancer Yvette Martinez and the drummer Nancy Friedman. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Admission is free December through February; the rest of the year it is $4; students and 65+, $2; under 6, free; Tuesdays, free all day; Saturdays, free 9 a.m. to noon. (718) 549-3200.
Events
New York City

'LARAMIE INSIDE OUT,' New York University, Tisch School of the Arts, 721 Broadway, near Waverly Place, Room 006, Greenwich Village. Today at 4 p.m., ''Laramie Inside Out,'' a short 2004 documentary film by Beverly Seckinger about the 1998 murder of Matthew Shepard, a gay college student in Laramie, Wyo.; a discussion with Ms. Seckinger and others follows. Free. (212) 998-7608.

BROOKLYN PUBLIC LIBRARY, Grand Army Plaza, Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Park Slope. Free author talks: tomorrow at 2 p.m., a reading by Anne Bailey from her novel ''African Voices of the Atlantic Slave Trade: Beyond the Silence and the Shame''; tomorrow at 4 p.m., Thulani Davis, author of ''My Confederate Kinfolk.'' Sunday at 2 p.m., Fred Jerome, author of ''Einstein on Race and Racism.''

OPEN HOUSE NEW YORK, public forums in design, planning and preservation, will feature a talk and tour about the architect Stanford White, featuring Sam White, his grandson, also an architect. Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m. at the General Theological Seminary, Ninth Avenue and 20th Street, Chelsea. Fee: $10. (212) 626-6869.

'CARNAVAL TIPICO DOMINICANO,' Aaron Davis Hall, City College, Convent Avenue and West 135th Street, Hamilton Heights. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a performance of Dominican music and dance with Joseito Mateo y Grupo Cultural Tipico Dominicano and others; tickets: $10 (children, $5). At the hall through May 5, ''Caribbean Celebrations: Port of Spain to New York City,'' photographs by Ray Llanos. Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and during performances. (212) 650-7100.

MORRIS-JUMEL MANSION, 65 Jumel Terrace, Edgecombe Avenue, at 160th Street, Washington Heights. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. ''Happy Birthday George,'' a free tribute to George Washington with activities and tours of the mansion where Washington stayed during the Revolutionary War's Battle of Harlem Heights. Through Feb. 26, ''Caribbean Connections,'' an exhibition on the Caribbean roots of the original owner of the mansion, Stephen Jumel, and artwork by Carlton Murrell and Alfred Weekes, artists born in Barbados. Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; students and 62+, $3; under 12, free. Guided tours Saturdays at noon ($5; students and 62+, $3). (212) 923-8008.

WATSON ADVENTURES Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m., ''The Grand Central Scramble for Families,'' a one-hour family hunt for the secrets of the stations. Fee: $15; ages 7 to 12, $10. Meeting place: (212) 726-1529.

COBI'S PLACE, 158 West 48th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m., ''Tribute to Fayard Nicholas,'' a lecture and film program about the dancer who died last month at age 91, followed by an open mic and an open tap; with Delilah Jackson, a jazz historian. Fee: $5. Sponsored by the Jazz Center of New York. (516) 922-2010.

CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK GRADUATE CENTER, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. Tonight at 6:30, ''International/World Theater: Thousand Years Waiting,'' a performance and discussion devoted to otome bunraku Japanese puppetry, featuring Masaya Kiritake, a puppeteer; Sonoko Kawahara, a director; and Chiori Miyagawa, a playwright. Free. (212) 817-8215.
Walking Tours
New York City

OUTDOORS CLUB Sunday at 11:30 a.m., ''Brooklyn Botanic Garden -- Crown Heights to Clinton Hill,'' a six-mile walk through the garden and surrounding neighborhoods, ending with dinner at an African restaurant. Meets outside the Eastern Parkway entrance to the garden. Fee: $3. (212) 348-5344.

DR. PHIL's NEW YORK WALKS AND TALKS Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., ''George Washington and Slavery in New York'' focuses on New York City during Washington's time; meets inside Blimpie's Restaurant, 38 Park Row. Fee: $15. (718) 591-4741 or (888) 377-4455.

MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Sunday at 1 p.m., ''Downtown Brooklyn'' looks at landmark buildings (and those that should be) in an area designated for development. Meets in Brooklyn, behind Borough Hall, on Joralemon Street, between Court Street and Boerum Place. Fee: $15 ($12 for members). (212) 935-3960.

BOWERY AND CANAL WALKING TOURS Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Madison to Union Square,'' covering the history and famous residents of the area, meets in front of the Seward statue, East 23rd Street and Broadway. Fee, $12; $10 for 65+ and students. (212) 979-8013.
'THE CHARMS OF CHELSEA' meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the northwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 15th Street. Sponsored by I'll Take Manhattan Tours. Fee: $12. (732) 270-5559.

MIKE'S NEW YORK CITY TOURS Monday at 10:30 a.m., ''Garment Center Holiday Bargain Shopping,'' a tour of showrooms and warehouses, meets in the lobby of 1410 Broadway, at 39th Street. Fee: $15. (212) 370-4214.

STREET SMARTS N.Y. Tomorrow at 6 p.m., ''Elegance and Ale'' tours three historic taverns; meets at the Washington Square Arch, southern end ofFifth Avenue, Greenwich Village; drinks and tips not included in tour fee. Fee: $10. (212) 969-8262.

HARLEM, YOUR WAY! Tomorrow at noon, ''Sights and Sounds Black Heritage Walking Tour of Harlem'' meets at 129 West 130th Street. Fee: $25; an optional meal follows. Reservations required: (212) 690-1687.

BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Monday at 1 p.m., ''Revolutionary New York'' covers Lower Manhattan sites associated with George Washington and the Revolutionary War, meeting at Broadway and Murray Street. Fee: $15; 63+, $12; students and New-York Historical Society members, $10. (212) 439-1090.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY Free tours of Central Park: Tomorrow at noon and Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Cross Park Promenade'' meets at the statue of Samuel F. B. Morse, at Fifth Avenue and 72nd Street. centralparknyc.org.

METRO TOUR SERVICE visits Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, today through Sunday at 2 p.m., meeting in front of the Marriott, Adams and Tillary Streets, downtown Brooklyn. Fee: $25. (718) 789-0430.
Attractions.
